Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Ila Varma is "Applications of Arithmetic Invariant Theory to Extensions of Cohen-Lenstra Heuristics and Beyond." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Benedict Gross.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI completed novel research mostly related to class group asymptotics and number field counting while supported by the NSF Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship. She held appointments at Harvard University and Columbia University during the grant award period.

The main topics of research focused on the even part of class groups of number fields with odd degree, the number of dihedral quartic fields ordered by conductor, asymptotics on ray and ring class groups of quadratic fields, and arithmetic and p-adic differential properties of unitary Shimura varieties. In addition, she has started new projects, including those on Malle's conjecture for Galois octic fields, unit signatures for odd abelian fields, and more general class group and number field asymptotics.

Most notably, two articles she co-authored that were submitteed prior to the award were accepted into Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society and Directions in Number Theory 3, another co-authored article was written, submitted, and accepted to Duke Mathematical Journal, and one single-author article and one co-authored paper have been written and submitted. The PI was able to attend many conferences and workshops around the globe, and give seminars and colloquia at many institutions with varied audiences. 

In addition, the PI was involved in numerous broader impact activities, including for the Program in Mathematics for Young Scientists (PROMYS), the Association for Women in Mathematics (AWM) Chapter at Columbia University, and Bridge to Enter Advanced Mathematics (BEAM) in NYC. The PI also co-organized an REU with a symplectic topology professor on the relationship between arithmetic invariant theory and knot theory.
